Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Calibrating the Cryogenian in the Yukon
Award.AbstractNarration:
COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Calibrating the Cryogenian in the Yukon

Francis MacDonald.1148499, Harvard University;
Mark Schmitz.1148058, Boise State University

ABSTRACT
The Snowball Earth hypothesis has galvanized broad interest in Neoproterozoic geology; however, the hypothesis remains controversial largely due to uncertainty about the timing, duration, and initiation mechanism of global glaciation. With previous and preliminary studies, we have demonstrated that the age of Sturtian glacial deposits in the Yukon is indistinguishable from the age of the Franklin large igneous province (LIP), which was emplaced on the eastern margin of Laurentia, in the tropics, in an ideal position for being chemically weathered. This is intriguing, because basalt is more weatherable than average continental crust, and it has been proposed that Snowball Earth events were initiated by an increase in weatherbility and a concomitant increase in CO2 consumption. However, the age range and error bars on the Franklin LIP are still too large to determine if the volcanism was long- or short-lived, and if the glaciation occurred during, before or after the main pulse of volcanism. With the proposed research PIs intend to constrain the timing and duration of the Sturtian glaciation and the Franklin LIP in the Yukon with high resolution U-Pb ID-TIMS dating of magmatic zircons and LA-ICPMS dating of detrital zircons that bracket the glacial deposits.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Neoproterozoic Snowball Earth events represent the largest episodes of climate change in the geological record. These glacial events also broadly coincide with the origin of animals and large changes in the chemical composition of the ocean and atmosphere. Uncertainty remains about the timing, duration, and initiation mechanism of global glaciation. Through geological, geochemical, and geochronological studies we have demonstrated that the timing of onset of Sturtian Snowball Earth is indistinguishable from the age of the Franklin large igneous province (LIP). We further dated multiple horizons in the pre-Sturtian Copper Cap and Twitya formations in the Northwest Territories that bound Sturtian-age glacial deposits and demonstrated that the Sturtian glaciation lasted ~57 million years. Refined ages from volcanic complexes Arctic Alaska, British Columbia, and Idaho support this age model. Additional ages from the Callison Lake Formation on fossiliferous deposits provided a new constraint on the last appearance datum of vase-shaped microfossils and suggested their use for biostratigraphy. Additionally age constraints on the Islay carbon isotope excursion demonstrate that it occurred ~10 Myrs before the onset of the Sturtian glaciation and that this perturbation to the carbon cycle cannot be related to the initiation of glaciation.

This grant has also promoted new collaborations with investigators working on correlative strata to the south along the North American Cordillera, and fieldwork has identified other volcanic strata that may be possible correlatives to the strata in the Yukon. This grant partially funded Vincent Isakson, a Ph.D. student at Boise State University, in a dissertation focusing on geochronology, and Athena Eyster and Judy Pu, Ph.D students at Harvard. All of these young scientists intend to follow careers in the Earth Science.

To promote the broader impacts of this project, co-PI Macdonald constructed a module about Snowball Earth at the Harvard Museum of Natural History. This includes video content projected on a hemispherical screen that animates large-scale climate change with narration.  At Boise State, co-PIs Schmitz and Viskupic created the “ZirChron App”, on-line Javascript and HTML-based application that allows Earth science students to explore real LA-ICPMS and ID-TIMS U-Pb zircon data sets and the observations and decisions that go into the interpretation of geochronology. The application and associated curriculum is part of the On the Cutting Edge Exemplary Teaching Collection and is disseminated globally through websites maintained by the Science Education Resource Center at Carleton College and the Boise State University Isotope Geology Laboratory.

Extreme alternative climate states like the “Snowball Earth” scenario provide the broader public with opportunities to consider and reflect on the possible ways that Earth’s environment can change. Studies that reveal the details of this change can provide a means to initiate and engage the public in this endeavor.
